projects.title: In Crisis, Again: Understanding the Endurance of Opioids & Combatting the Modern Epidemic
projects.description:
Onset by overprescribing and mismarketing, the modern opioid crisis that has commanded public attention for the past three decades has taken more than 800,000 lives since 1999 and has only worsened in the strain of recent years. (CDC) Notwithstanding, the modern crisis bears a lot of similarities to the nation’s first opioid epidemic seen in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. Communities faced what would be the first national opioid epidemic a century before the infamous mismarketing of OxyContin and impact of widespread opioid abuse dominating news outlets today. The emergence, exploitation, and eruption of both epidemics follow the same arcs in history, yet the de-escalation of the earlier epidemic has faded into distant memory and recovery from the most recent has yet to be seen.
The lingering stigma of opioid abuse manufactured by pharmaceutical companies and federal regulations in the early 19th century has endured and still creates an isolating environment for those in need today, leaving them with economic, cultural, and geographical barriers to recovery. Learning from the earlier epidemic, understanding the physiology of addiction and why we are repeating mistakes from the past, and making proven treatments such as MAT, or Medication-Assisted Treatment, widely available can help to alleviate future escalation of the modern opioid crisis. Accessible recovery in conjunction with the de-stigmatization of that which was left unamended by the earlier epidemic is what is needed to prevent future devastation and build a system that can prevent history from repeating itself once again.
projects.author: Molly Cook

projects.title: Hanging by a Thread
projects.subtitle: Visualizing the life of a garment and its effects on the environment
projects.description:
The lifecycle of a garment begins with raw materials and ends in a landfill. The process is lengthy and often hidden from consumers. Excess waste and pollution is created by the fashion industry and is harming the environment, contributing 4% of annual global greenhouse gas emissions. Due to fast fashion increasing in popularity, garments are being created to be disposable. This is increasing the rate of production and decreasing the length of time a garment is in use. In order to combat these issues, new solutions need to be created. Sustainable fashion is the concept of designing and creating clothing that will minimize the negative impact the process has on the environment. 
The fashion industry is responsible for more annual carbon emissions than all international flights and maritime shipping combined. If the industry maintains linear production, greenhouse gasses are expected to increase by 50% within the decade. Analyzing each step of production is crucial to understanding what needs to be redesigned. Studies show that slow fashion and circular design for fashion are ideas that will potentially minimize waste production. This project will bring transparency to where clothing comes from by examining the production methods in the fast fashion industry and its effect on the environment. As well as, analyzing possible solutions to advocate for a more sustainable fashion industry and a more mindful consumer.
projects.author: Juliet Craig

projects.title: Memories around the corner
projects.subtitle: Mapping NYC honorary street names
projects.description:
NYC honorary street names, or co-names enacted by the City Council, can be found above or below the primary street-name signs throughout the five boroughs of NYC. Over the 30 years enactment of this practice documented officially, communities, local activists, and politicians have petitioned {number} of honorary street names, to honor people or organizations of special significance to a particular community or neighborhood. Simultaneously, co-names can be seen as an approach to remap the city in a local sense, interweaving its past, present, and future. However, for considerations of legal and bureaucratic costs, honorary street names have never been accessible to the public either through an analog city map or a digital database.
How are communities in NYC preserving their heritage through commemorative street naming? And How have co-names entangled with the cultural/political atmosphere? This project surveys the NYC honorary street names, by applying both quantitative and qualitative analysis and data visualization. The source data are collected and parsed from the City Council’s legislation files, and further aggregated with GIS information and text analysis. As a result, this project transforms the practice of honorary street names into a more accessible format and creates a generated city landscape of memory.
projects.author: Jessie Han

projects.title: The Global Theatrics of a Global Meltdown
projects.description:
All around the world, countries are witnessing the different effects of climate change. The island nation of Tuvalu, which is home to around 11,000 people, has witnessed sea levels rise by about 0.5 centimeters every year since 1993. The Maldives, a well-known bucket list getaway, is the lowest-lying nation in the world. Therefore, sea-level rise caused by global climate change is an existential threat to the island nation. Finally, Iceland, a cold island nation in the Atlantic ocean actually has the opposite problem. Land in Iceland is rising at a pace of as much as 1.4 inches per year in certain areas as a result of climate change, according to a new study. Like the rest of the world, these countries have much to gain from stopping climate change. A main combatant in the fight is ESG focused investing and decision making, which has increased emphasis and interest, both from investors and the public, in sustainable and responsible investments. This study attempts to answer questions about the current state of ESG friendly strategy worldwide, and how it is affecting the global meltdown. The study therefore aims to inform the reader as to how their country’s government and businesses are actually combating climate change. 
The results of the study show that ESG investing and governmental action is increasing worldwide. One of the main focus points of combating climate change is through ESG investing and decision making. These investments have been gaining momentum recently. In 2021, a record $649 billion poured into ESG-focused funds worldwide, up from the $542 billion and $285 billion in 2020 and 2019, respectively. But despite that, governments worldwide spend at least $1.8 trillion each year—equal to 2% of global GDP—on subsidies that are accelerating the destruction of our natural world.
projects.author: Gisli Gudjonsson

projects.title: Ripe for Disruption
projects.subtitle: Climate Change and the Future of the Wine Industry
projects.description:
Winemakers are some of the most seasoned climate scientists in the world. Agricultural techniques required for harvesting grapes accumulated over decades (sometimes centuries), coupled with precise knowledge of environmental patterns surrounding their vineyards, provide winemakers with unrivaled expertise and effective methods to optimize wine production. Because climate is the most essential ingredient required for wine production, it affects the level of suitability of grape varieties to a particular terrain, and determines the type and quality of the wine that can be produced. However, recent extreme weather events also confirm that grapes are extremely sensitive to sudden changes in temperature and other unforeseen fluctuations. These shifts raise difficult questions for the wine industry and could potentially disrupt centuries of cultural practices and agricultural norms in winemaking while also unlocking new opportunities in adapting to climate change, something that will require innovation and flexibility.
While the topic of climate change in the wine industry attracts much media and academic attention and generates important discussions within the wine industry, most of the existing empirical evidence is either geographically localized, confined to a specific grape variety, and/or difficult to grasp for wine enthusiasts. In addition, it is also difficult for a wine aficionado to access updated and/or user-friendly applications of cutting-edge climate change information suited for the wine industry.  The Ripe for Disruption project provides a glimpse into the future of the wine industry, by using geovisualization tools to help the reader better grasp which wine regions (and wineries) are more likely to be on the frontlines of global warming in the future. A closer look at extreme weather events that recently impacted the “Old World '' and the “New World '' is also provided to make sense of these macro-level shifts, before finally, exploring the different opportunities and adaptive changes the wine industry might go through as a result.
projects.author: Yann Kerblat

projects.title: Is Food Making You Sick?
projects.subtitle: Exploring the Relationship Between Nutrition and Health
projects.description:
Today, diseases related to nutrition have been increasing steeply, overburdening the healthcare system with a devastating human toll. As the COVID-19 pandemic has shown, conditions such as ischaemic heart disease, diabetes, cancer, and other non-infectious diseases, are not only causing the death of millions of people around the world each year, but are also risk factors, increasing the severity of other diseases.  Although we are not able to affect all of our risk factors, we can still improve our overall health through nutrition.
Is Food Making You Sick? Exploring the Relationship Between Nutrition and Health is studying the relationship between diet and health in 184 countries through the analysis and visualization of extensive data on nutritional factors and diseases. It aims to study and visualize these relationships by juxtaposing the various nutrition and health metrics, allowing users to explore and analyze them. 
The project Is Food Making You Sick? Exploring the Relationship Between Nutrition and Health will answer questions such as do countries that have a high fat diet, also struggle with heart disease? Do countries consuming high amounts of sugar are overburdened with diabetes and vice versa? Empowered with this information by exploring the patterns between food consumption and health outcomes, users could better inform their dietary choices. Exposing the data visually could also spark discussion amongst researchers about less researched correlations, setting the stage for testing hypotheses and performing studies.
projects.author: Yoana Kosturska

projects.title: What is blind box, and why did it go viral?
projects.description:
With the increasing wealth of Generation Z and the rapid diversification of entertainment, the blind box industry has made a big splash in the financial market. A blind box is a package with mystery contents that customers purchase from a particular brand. Under the leadership of some blind box companies and social media accounts, blind boxes have achieved huge market success in China in recent years. When toys become the hobby of "adults", they bring cultural and business opportunities and challenges that should not be underestimated. Blind boxes, it may be inferred, have met customers' psychology of curiosity, pursuit of beauty, nostalgic mood, and need for companionship.

What is blind box, and why did it go viral? presents the history of how the blind box market developed since it was introduced to China and explores the psychological reasons why people are so addicted to it. This data visualization project focuses on how the blind box market became popular, the huge potential behind it, and why people are so addicted to blind boxes, as well as the psychological research behind it. Viewers of this project can get to know the famous IPs, the comparison with art toys, and filter out the economic growth and potential financial market year by year with both text narration and visual presentations.
projects.author: Wenqin Lu

projects.title: From the ground up
projects.subtitle: Exploring edible and medicinal plant data for sustainable systems
projects.description: From the Ground Up explores the current landscape of plant data presently available to potential growers with the aim of fostering participation, curiosity, and confidence in applying plant data. The project explores data aggregated from Plants for a Future, USDA, and National Gardening Association to invite users to identify plant cultivation needs and practical uses that fit their needs. The visualizations focus on representing use cases most relevant to urban farming in New York City, prioritizing data for plants that grow successfully in temperate climate zones. Users can filter data for more than 7,000 plants based on plant needs, plant tolerances, and aggregated consumable uses. The visualizations further connect to other online resources and provide information to enable users’ self-education and encourage in-person connection and continued participation in sustainable food growing practices in their communities and at home. From the Ground Up aims to make plant research more exciting and accessible to larger communities and to implement modern data practices within collective horticultural knowledge.
projects.author: Shea Molloy

projects.description:
New York City is by many measures the most culturally diverse city as well as one of the most socioeconomically diverse cities in America. Additionally, New York City has by far the largest population, and the most comprehensive intercity transit system of any American city. These factors put together have created the conditions for a diverse and interesting population of subway riders in NYC. Many people recognize and appreciate this fact, as there are several extremely popular social media accounts that capture the quirks, beautiful moments, and many inadequacies of the city's subway system (subwayhands, peopleofpennstation, and subwaycreatures to name a few of them).
While these social media accounts provide a highly subjective and qualitative view of the demographics of the subway system, there have not been many efforts to quantify and visualize these demographics. This is important because these demographics, quirks, and inadequacies of the subway system have their roots in many different factors, including city politics, systemic inequality, and the hyper-capitalistic structure of the city itself. Additionally, the demographics of the subway can morph slowly or change almost instantly, as was the case when NYC became the country’s first major hotspot for COVID-19. Similar, but smaller changes can also occur, such as Eric Adams’ ongoing effort to remove homeless people from the subway.

This visualization seeks to present a humanistic perspective of the diversity of the city, from the inside of a subway car. The inside of a subway car itself is a visual representation of how many people are riding the subway at the current time as well as what kinds of people. This visualization shows how the demographics of subway ridership has changed both gradually and dramatically over time. The visualization takes into account actual subway ridership data, neighborhood demographic data, as well as public health and political events to provide a holistic representation of the city’s demographics over time.
